params.note: Initial SNR isolation using stereoscope may be difficult; isolated tissue may contain no SNRs, a small SNR, or multiple rosettes, often leading to failed organoid growth or transformation.
SNR size and shape vary substantially within a single well; most often isolated SNRs are at least 200 μm in diameter with a clearly distinguishable single lumen, regardless of lumen or rosette shape.
Isolated SNRs have mean diameter of 297 ± 3 μm (95% CI: 290.6–303.3 μm) with variable shapes, potentially influencing cell identity and distribution in derived organoids.

New methods using spatially confined micropatterned substrates can generate uniform SNRs with defined size and shape, potentially enhancing organoid generation efficiency and enabling studies on SNR size/shape effects.

Organoid tissue lamination is non-uniform; regions with predictable neural organization coexist with regions of unclear or no organization, which are visually identifiable and excluded from imaging and electrophysiology analyses.
Impact of disorganized organoid areas on overall development remains unclear.

Common limitations of organoid protocols include absence of vasculature (limiting oxygen/nutrient delivery), lack of microglia (affecting cell/synapse regulation), and absence of sensory/brain region inputs (limiting information flow recapitulation).
Xenotransplantation of human organoids into rodent brain has been used to partially overcome these limitations.

Organoid generation protocol consists of five stages: (1) PS cell maintenance and propagation, (2) neural induction, (3) NR formation and isolation, (4) organoid formation from isolated SNRs, (5) organoid maturation.
Additional procedures include generation of CRISPR-Cas9-engineered human stem cells with large genetic deletions, scRNA-seq, immunohistochemistry, and slice patch-clamp electrophysiology.
It is essential to use validated and characterized human stem cell lines; insufficiently characterized lines may lead to irreproducible results.
Follow standards for human stem cell use released by the International Society for Stem Cell Research.

Well-characterized human stem cell lines are available from WiCell, Allen Institute for Cell Sciences, National Institute of Mental Health, Simons Foundation Autism Research Initiative, and California Institute for Regenerative Medicine.
For disease modeling, include isogenic engineered lines as controls.

Conditional CRE- or FLP-mediated induction/rescue of genetic abnormalities during differentiation is the most controlled approach, successfully used for autism, schizophrenia, and Alzheimer’s disease studies.
This controlled approach has not yet been used for studying large genetic abnormalities.
In a previous study, a pair of guide RNAs was used to excise a complete copy of SHANK3 (~69.5 kB) in human PS cells.
